content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata> <idinfo> <citation> <citeinfo> <origin>S.T. Saalfeld and R.B. Lanctot, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Division of Migratory Bird Management.</origin> <pubdate>2012</pubdate> <title>Arctic PRISM Plot Survey Data. U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Division of Migratory Bird Management (2012).</title> <geoform>vector digital data</geoform> <pubinfo> <pubplace>Fairbanks, AK</pubplace> <publish>Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative</publish> </pubinfo> <onlink>http://arcticlcc.org/products/spatial-data/show/north-slope-prism-shorebird-location-and-plot-survey-geodatabase</onlink> </citeinfo> </citation> <descript> <abstract>This dataset consists of a polygon vector file representing 767 plots surveyed as part of the Program for Regional and International Shorebird Monitoring (PRISM).  For each plot, information pertaining to shorebird abundance, occupancy, and species richness is provided.  This dataset was derived from single-visit rapid area shorebird surveys in which 1-2 surveyors recorded all suspected breeding shorebirds within the plot boundary.  These data were acquired over the Arctic Coastal Plain of Alaska during nine years between 1998 and 2008 (surveys not conducted in 2003 and 2005).</abstract> <purpose>This dataset was developed with the intention of estimating breeding abundance, distribution, and habitat associations of shorebirds across the Arctic Coastal Plain of Alaska.</purpose> <supplinf> Dataset Limitations: As PRISM protocols were being developed over the course of this study, methods for plot selection varied among years.  In early years (1998 - 2001), plots were randomly selected in the NPR-A within habitat strata (wetland and upland), where plot boundaries followed natural borders between wetlands and uplands (excluding unsuitable habitat [e.g., open water, mudflats]), resulting in variable plot sizes (2 - 342 ha) and shapes.  In later years (2002 - 2008), plot sizes were restricted to 400 x 400 m2 square plots (16 ha) and were primarily located randomly, with a few plots located nonrandomly.  For logistical reasons, in 2001, 2002, and 2004, plots were located in 2- and 3- plot clusters, where second and third plots were selected randomly within 1 - 5 km from the initial plot.  Furthermore, in early years, search effort (i.e., amount of time spent surveying plot) was not standardized among plots.  Thus, differences in plot selection method, clustering of plots, size and shape of plots, and survey effort may influence comparability of shorebird abundance, occupancy, and species richness among plots or years. Additionally, in 2006, a portion of plots originally surveyed in 2001 within the NPR-A were surveyed again as part of a project to monitor avian influenza.  Because each plot is only represented once in the dataset, we combined years for these repeat sampled plots, and considered a species as present if it was detected during at least one survey.  However, number of individuals and estimated pairs is based on one randomly chosen survey.  When interpreting these data, the user should be aware that the detectability of shorebirds is a function of many variables, including differences in species, habitat, time-of-year, weather conditions, survey effort, and individual surveyor.  Methodology During 9 years between 1998 and 2008 (surveys not conducted in 2003 and 2005), ground surveys were conducted as part of the Program for Regional and International Shorebird Monitoring (PRISM).  As PRISM protocols were being developed over the course of this study, methods for plot selection varied among years.  Detailed descriptions of plot selection methods for 1998 - 2004 can be found in Bart and Earnst (2002), Brown et al. (2007), Johnson et al. (2007), and Bart et al. (2012).  Briefly, in early years (1998 - 2001), plots were randomly selected in the NPR-A within habitat strata (wetland and upland), where plot boundaries followed natural borders between wetlands and uplands (excluding unsuitable habitat [e.g., open water, mudflats]), resulting in variable plot sizes (2 - 342 ha) and shapes.  In later years (2002 - 2008), plot sizes were restricted to 400 x 400 m2 square plots (16 ha) and were primarily located randomly, with a few plots located nonrandomly.  In 2002 and 2004, plots were located within the ANWR and west to the Colville River (eastern boarder of the NPR-A) independent of habitat type (in 2002) or based on stratified habitat types (in 2004; riparian, flooded, very wet, and upland developed from Jorgenson et al. [1994] ).  For logistical reasons, in 2001, 2002, and 2004, plots were located in 2- and 3- plot clusters, where second and third plots were selected randomly within 1 - 5 km from the initial plot.  In 2006, a portion of plots originally surveyed in 2001 within the NPR-A were surveyed again as part of a project to monitor avian influenza.  In 2007 and 2008, plots were randomly located within the Teshekpuk Lake Special Area (TLSA) of the NPR-A.  To ensure plots were surveyed throughout the entire region, we divided the TLSA into 4 geographic areas (NW, NE, SE, and SW) based on predominant land cover types defined for the NPR-A by Ducks Unlimited, Inc. (1998).  Within each geographic area, plots were selected randomly proportional to the relative area.  Plot locations were restricted in both 2007 and 2008 so as not to be the same as those sampled in 2001, and plot locations in 2008 so as not to be the same as plots sampled in 2007. In all years, shorebirds were surveyed during pre- and early incubation periods (i.e., 7 June - 1 July) when breeding shorebirds were most detectable.  Surveys were conducted using a single-visit, rapid area search technique, where 1 - 2 surveyors systematically traversed each plot and recorded the presence of all suspected breeding shorebirds within the plot boundary.  An individual bird's behavior (e.g., territorial and courtship displays, attachment to the plot) was used to assess whether the pair was likely breeding in or very near the plot.  Transient birds (e.g., flyovers) were not included in counts.  The attributes associated with this polygon vector file consist of: Plot: unique value assigned to each plot within a given year and recorded from original data ID: unique value assigned to all plots; created to provide a unique identifier for all plots (a few plots have the same Plot value in subsequent years) in a consistent format (numeric) Month: month in which survey was conducted; Value -999 corresponds to missing values Day: day on which survey was conducted; Value -999 corresponds to missing values Year: year in which survey was conducted Time: amount of time spent surveying plot (min); Value -999 corresponds to missing values AMGP_A: number of American Golden-Plovers (Pluvialis dominica) detected on plot BASA_A: number of Baird's Sandpipers (Calidris bairdii) detected on plot BBPL_A: number of Black-bellied Plovers (Pluvialis squatarola) detected on plot BBSA_A: number of Buff-breasted Sandpipers (Trygnites subruficollis) detected on plot BTGO_A: number of Bar-tailed Godwits (Limosa lapponica) detected on plot DUNL_A: number of Dunlin (Calidris alpina) detected on plot LBDO_A: number of Long-billed Dowitchers (Limnodromus scolopaceus) detected on plot LEYE_A: number of Lesser Yellowlegs (Tringa flavipes) detected on plot PESA_A: number of Pectoral Sandpipers (Calidris melanotos) detected on plot REKN_A: number of Red Knots (Calidris canutus) detected on plot REPH_A: number of Red Phalaropes (Phalaropus fulicaria) detected on plot RNPH_A: number of Red-necked Phalaropes (Phalaropus lobatus) detected on plot RUTU_A: number of Ruddy Turnstones (Arenaria interpres) detected on plot SAND_A: number of Sanderlings (Calidris alba) detected on plot SEPL_A: number of Semipalmated Plovers (Charadrius semipalmatus) detected on plot SESA_A: number of When interpreting these data, the user should be aware that the detectability of shorebirds is a function of many variables, including differences in species, habitat, time-of-year, weather conditions, survey effort, and individual surveyor. </attraccr> </attracc> <logic>QA/QC completed by Originator.</logic> <complete>These data do not represent all locations within the study area where shorebirds may be present, as shorebirds were only surveyed in discrete survey plots.  Additionally, individuals may have went undetected within survey plots, as detectability was likely less that 100%, and is a function of many variables, including differences in species, habitat, time-of-year, weather conditions, survey effort, and individual surveyor.</complete> <lineage> <procstep> <procdesc>Shorebird sighting data collected in the field were linked with surveyed plots in
